key_title: Key to the species of Rubus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Rosaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C.
source.title: Rosaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C. (1996). Rosaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves palmately or pedately compound, mostly with 5 leaflets; drupelets usually black, sometimes red, not falling from receptacle when ripe
Leaves simple or pinnately compound with 3, 5 or 7 leaflets; drupelets red or orange, falling from receptacle when ripe (persistent and black in R. loganobaccus)
Leaves simple (but often shallowly 3–5-lobed)
Leaves ternate or pinnately compound (but sometimes with a few lobed leaves)
Stems, petioles and sepals densely covered with long, reddish gland-tipped bristles; leaves 3-foliolate; petals incurved
Stems and sepals not as above; leaves pinnately compound, or with a mixture of simple and compound leaves on the same plant; petals erect or spreading
Leaflets green on both surfaces; canes sparsely hairy; glands sometimes present on canes and leaflets
Leaflets white-tomentose below; young canes densely hairy, glabrescent; glands absent
Stem prickles abundant, strong, hooked, mostly more than 1 mm long; fruit red
Stem prickles absent or sparse, weak, more or less straight, usually less than 1 mm long; fruit red or orange
All leaves compound; stipules entire or 2-lobed; fruits formed; widespread

Plants usually with a mixture of compound and simple lobed leaves; stipules usually 2-lobed, occasionally up to 4-lobed or entire; fruits never formed; restricted to warm temperate rainforest in eastern Victoria
Glands absent; fruit red or black, not falling from receptacle when ripe
Glands present on canes and leaves; fruit red falling from receptacle when ripe
[link through]
Leaves 3(–5)-lobed; veins on the upper surface of the leaves flat to slightly impressed; the upper leaf surface not or only indistinctly bullately raised; mature fruit red

Leaves 5(–7)-lobed; veins on the upper leaf surface deeply impressed; the upper leaf surface distinctly bullate (projections 0.7-1 mm high) all over or sometimes mainly near margins in older leaves; mature fruit purplish black
[link through]
Leaflets deeply and irregularly cut into narrow lobes, sometimes nearly to midrib, or rarely leaflets undivided, green below; apex of petals often notched
Leaflets variously toothed, never cut into deep, narrow lobes, green to grey-green or white below; apex of petals usually entire
Stems (especially floricanes), petioles, stipules, axis, peduncles and sepals with numerous stalked glandular hairs; sepals armed
Stalked glandular hairs absent or sparse, if ever numerous then largely restricted to axis and peduncles; sepals armed or unarmed
Lower surface of leaflets green, with sparse pilose hairs
Lower surface of leaflets grey-green due to moderate cover of short grey pubescent hairs
Leaflets green below, scarcely tomentose, lamina surface usually visible
Leaflets grey-green to white below, the lamina usually obscured by short tomentose hair
At least the inflorescence with some scattered glandular hairs
Glandular hairs absent
Axis and peduncles with dense long, erect hairs, lacking shorter tomentose hairs
Axis and peduncles with moderate to dense cover of short tomentose hairs, sometimes  with scattered longer pilose hairs
Stems glabrous or with sparse hairs
Stems pubescent
High arching plants; stems glabrescent when young, soon becoming glabrous, not pruinose; leaves usually palmately compound; petals flat or channelled
Plants spreading; stems not high-arching, pubescent or glabrous and pruinose; leaves usually pedately compound; petals cupped or crumpled
Largest leaflets not more the 3.5 cm wide, the undersurface with few or no pilose hairs; older stems usually pruinose; stamens more or less equal to styles
Largest leaflets often more than 4 cm wide, the undersurface with few to many pilose hairs; stems remaining pubescent, not pruinose; stamens exceeding styles
[link through]
